Infotracer Scholarship
InfoTracer offers a great service to consumers, but we also care about community involvement. We are offering eligible students the opportunity to win $1,000 in scholarship money for college for the 2022-2023 school year.
Application Procedure
Download a copy of the application on the scholarship website
Include a copy of the front and back of your military or student ID.
Include your most recent cumulative transcript (unofficial) showing grades through June, 2022 on a 4.0 GPA rating scale.
You will also need to write a 1000-word essay. Your article should be interesting, engaging and informative to the reader.
Application Restrictions
There is no age requirement to apply for this grant.
This program is open to all legal residents and citizens of the United States and all its territories.
Employees of InfoTracer.com, are not eligible to apply.
Void where prohibited by law.
You must submit your completed application package by December 31, 2022, to scholarships@InfoTracer.com.
To learn more and start your application, click on the Visit button below. more...

Internship Plus Program
This program awards up to $2,500 in financial assistance to eligible undergraduate students working in a quarter-long unpaid internship. The Internship Plus program was established to support DePaul University undergraduate students participating in unpaid internships that demonstrate financial need. All awards are issued as scholarships to the student’s tuition account and are treated as financial aid. Please speak with Student Accounts to confirm what impact this will have on your tuition account and how money will be disbursed if there are no current tuition charges.
In order to be eligible for this award, you must fill out the general scholarship application as well as the Internship Plus application, and the following requirements must be met AT THE TIME OF YOUR APPLICATION, no exceptions:
Must be a current full-time undergraduate student during the quarter of your internship. For summer awards, students must be enrolled full-time during the quarter following their internship. You must be enrolled full time for the upcoming quarter at the time of your application.
Be in good academic and disciplinary standing with the University, with a minimum cumulative GPA of 2.5/4.0.
The student will be working in an UNPAID internship over the course of the academic term.
The student is not receiving any other scholarships/awards for this unpaid internship opportunity.
The student demonstrates an understanding of their internship role and organization and have articulated the value of this internship experience within their application.
The student demonstrates financial need.
Students should have an offer for an unpaid internship, but can still apply if they haven’t fully accepted the offer. Please note that applicants with fully confirmed internships will be prioritized over those with internships still being developed.
To apply for this scholarship, you must answer the following questions completely in short-essay format. A large part of our assessment will focus on how this internship will impact your professional and career development and what you hope to learn in your internship in relation to your major or field of interest, career exploration, and/or skill development. Your responses must be well thought out with little to no grammatical or spelling errors.
Scholarships are awarded on a rolling basis, which means that awards are made until funds are exhausted or the end of the application period.
For more info and FAQs, visit the website: https://resources.depaul.edu/career-center/jobs-internships/internships/Pages/Internship-Plus.aspx
If you have any questions, please feel free to reach out to the Employer Engagement team in the DePaul Career Center:
recruitstudents@depaul.edu
(312) 362-5201 more...

Internship Plus Scholarship
Each quarter, the Internship Plus Scholarship supports DePaul University undergraduate students who are working in a quarter-long, unpaid internship. To help offset some of the costs associated with an unpaid internship, the Internship Plus Scholarship awards up to $2,500 in financial assistance to eligible undergraduate students working in a quarter-long unpaid internship.
To be eligible to receive this award, students must:
• Be a current undergraduate student, enrolled full time and at least sophomore standing. Applicants must be returning to the college
after the completion of the internship. Students graduating at the end of the quarter for which they are applying are not eligible.
• Maintain a minimum cumulative GPA of 2.5 out of 4.0.
• Be working in an unpaid internship, recording a minimum of 80 hours over the course of the 10-week term.
• Neither receive any other scholarships or awards for this unpaid internship opportunity nor have received previous Internship Plus
funding.
• Demonstrate a clear understanding of how their internship is supporting their career plan.
• Demonstrate financial need both through your application responses and as determined by DePaul’s Office of Financial Aid and can
provide a breakdown of costs associated with working an unpaid internship.
To apply for this scholarship, you must answer the following questions completely in short-essay format. A large part of our assessment will focus on how this internship will impact your career plan, skill development, and learning goals. Your responses must be well thought out with attention to detail.
If you have any questions, please feel free to reach out to the Career Center at
internships@depaul.edu more...

J. Willard And Alice S. Marriott Foundation Hospitality Scholarship For Undergraduate Freshmen
Awarded to deserving freshmen undergraduates enrolled as majors or minors (or intended) in the School of Hospitality Leadership.
Through a recently establish partnership between DePaul University and the J. Willard and Alice S. Marriott Foundation, the DePaul University School of Hospitality Leadership is now accepting applications for the J. Willard and Alice S. Marriott Foundation Hospitality Scholarship. A total of 10 scholarships will be awarded with a value of $10,000 each.
This scholarship was designed to assist in the recruitment and development of DePaul University Freshman into a major or minor in the School of Hospitality Leadership. A freshman is an enrolled student that has no more than 48 credits on their official DePaul University transcript. Priority is given to those students who are the first in their immediate family to attend college and who come from disadvantaged backgrounds. Additionally, scholarship recipients are chosen based on demonstrated financial need, a desire to participate in a co-curricular student activity, such as belonging to hospitality clubs, and having a full or part time job in the hospitality industry. If awarded the scholarship, funds are paid to the student in a $5000 installment during the freshman year, and a second and final installment during the sophomore year, pending continued commitment to the School of Hospitality Leadership.
The scholarship application deadline for online submission is October 8, 2014 at 11:59:59 PM CST. Applications submitted after this deadline will not be considered.
Scholarship Requirements:
To apply for this scholarship complete and submit the following:
• Completed online application form;
• Current resume;
• Maximum 2 page essay (double-spaced, 12pt font, 1-inch margin pages) explaining why you feel you meet the scholarship recipient selection criteria.
Additional Information:
In addition to a $10,000 scholarship, award recipients will be automatically enrolled in the prestigious Marriott Hospitality Scholars Program (MHSP), and will be recognized as a “Marriott Scholar.” Benefits of being enrolled in the MHSP include, but are not limited to, the following:
1. Bi-weekly “Check-In” Meeting
2. Marriott Property Tours and Networking
3. Professional Development Workshops
4. Professional Development Essentials Kit
5. VIP Networking Event
6. MHSP Website
7. Scholar Mentorship more...

J. Willard And Alice S. Marriott Foundation Hospitality Scholarship For Undergraduate Juniors
Awarded to deserving junior undergraduates enrolled as majors or minors (or intended) in the School of Hospitality Leadership.
Through a recently establish partnership between DePaul University and the J. Willard and Alice S. Marriott Foundation, the DePaul University School of Hospitality Leadership is now accepting applications for the J. Willard and Alice S. Marriott Foundation Hospitality Scholarship. A total of 10 scholarships will be awarded with a value of $10,000 each.
This scholarship is designed to assist in the retention and development of existing DePaul University hospitality students as they successfully work towards completing their undergraduate degree. It is reserved for junior undergraduate students enrolled as majors or minors (or intended) in the School of Hospitality Leadership. A junior is an enrolled student that has at least 96 credits and no more than 144 credits on their official DePaul University transcript.
Priority is given to those students who are first in their family to attend college and who come from disadvantaged backgrounds. Additionally, scholarship recipients are chosen based on demonstrated financial need, academic performance, co-curricular student activity, such as belonging to hospitality clubs or holding club leadership positions, and having full or part time jobs in the hospitality industry. If awarded the scholarship, funds will be paid to the student in a $5000 installment during their junior year, and a second and final installment during their senior year, pending continued commitment to the School of Hospitality Leadership.
The scholarship application online submission deadline is October 8, 2014 at 11:59:59 PM CST. No applications will be considered if submitted past this deadline.
Scholarship Requirements:
To apply for this scholarship complete and submit the following:
• Completed online application form;
• Updated Transcript;
• Current resume;
• Maximum 2-page essay (double-spaced, 12pt font, 1-inch margins) explaining how receiving this scholarship will further your academic career at DePaul University.
Additional Information:
In addition to a $10,000 scholarship, award recipients will be automatically enrolled in the prestigious Marriott Hospitality Scholars Program (MHSP), and will be recognized as a “Marriott Scholar.” Benefits of being enrolled in the MHSP include, but are not limited to, the following:
1. Bi-weekly “Check-In” Meeting
2. Marriott Property Tours and Networking
3. Professional Development Workshops
4. Professional Development Essentials Kit
5. VIP Networking Event
6. MHSP Website
7. Scholar Mentorship more...

J. William & Pat Eddy Memorial Scholarship
Scholarship for undergraduate students attending Millikin University majoring in Chemistry or Physics. Deadlines and award amounts may vary. more...

J. William Record Scholarship
Scholarship for undergraduate students attending Millikin University. Preference is given to students in the School of Business. Deadlines and award amounts may vary. more...

J.H. & M.E. Leach Scholarship
Scholarship for incoming freshmen enrolling at Western Illinois University who are majoring in Family and Consumer Sciences or Community Health and Health Services Management. Applicants must have a minimum 3.0 GPA, minimum ACT score of 24 and graduated in the top 10% of class. Number of awards may vary. Renewable. more...

Jack & Deedee Brannigan Scholarship
The fund was established by John “Jack” Brannigan and his wife Deedee Brannigan from Northfield, Illinois.
CRITERIA:
Must have completed 60 semester hours by the end of the semester of application
Have a grade point average of between 2.5 and 3.0
One letter of recommendation no longer than one page more...

Jack & Margaret Oakley Memorial Scholarship
To continue Jack and Margaret Oakley’s legacy of their service and dedication to education, as well as compassion and meaningful impact on Lincoln Land Community College students, their family has established a scholarship endowment for students attending Lincoln Land Community College.
Jack was born and raised on an Illinois farm where he learned firsthand about agriculture. He followed several career paths throughout his life, but ultimately returned to agriculture and began working for the Farm Bureau. After serving as manager in several counties, he retired as manager of the Sangamon County Farm Bureau.
Margaret began working at Lincoln Land Community College (LLCC) as a clerk in the community services office. She quickly grew to love the college and began taking classes to further her education. While working full-time and raising a family, she earned her associate degree and went on to earn a bachelor’s degree at University of Illinois at Springfield (UIS). Margaret retired as an academic advisor after more than 25 years of service to LLCC.
Jack and Margaret’s daughters, Jackie, Susan, Laura and Mary offer this scholarship as a way to honor their parents who gave so much to them. Through this endowment, the Oakley’s legacy will be a continuation of that giving to help ease the financial burden for students in their academic pursuits.
ELIGIBILITY
1. Must have a minimum GPA of 2.0 on a 4.0 scale
2. Enrolled in an agriculture field of study
3. Available for a first-time freshman or continuing college student
4. Preference for a student for whatever reason had a break in their education
5. If no eligible agriculture student is identifiable, a student in a “helping” field of study shall be awarded more...

Jack & Margaret Stites Pre-Pharmacy Scholarship
The Margaret & Jack Stites Pre-Pharmacy Scholarship was established by Jack Stites in memory of his beloved wife, Margaret. CRITERIA: Enrolled at Western Illinois University, Pursuing the Pharmacy option in the Department of Chemistry, Must have completed 30 semester hours by the conclusion of the spring semester, Minimum grade point average of 3.5 is required, Financial need is not a consideration. Preference will be given to applicants that have actual pharmacy experience. more...

Jack Greer Student Development Fund Scholarship
This fund is being established by the Department of Automotive Technology to honor the career of Jack Greer. Jack spent 35 years at SIU training and developing hundreds of Automotive Technology students and worked side by side with the Automotive Racing Team on the Nova. He served 13 years as the Department Chair and was instrumental promoting and planning for the Transportation Education Center.
Recipients of the scholarship must be majoring in Automotive Technology. more...

Enrolled in the Teacher Education Program pursuing a degree in Elementary Education or Math Education preparing for a career of teaching mathematics, 2. Completed 60 semester hours (junior class level) by the conclusion of the spring semester, 3. Minimum 3.0 grade point average 4. Applicants must demonstrate a commitment to social responsibility that has resulted in significant personal growth. They will be expected to continue this commitment. BGS CRITERIA: 1. Enrolled in the Bachelor of General Studies (BGS) program
2. Completed 60 semester hours (junior class level) by the conclusion of the spring semester
3. Minimum 3.0 grade point average 4. Applicants must demonstrate a commitment to social responsibility that has resulted in significant personal growth. They will be expected to continue this commitment. more...

3.) The recipient(s) are eligible to apply for the award again provided they continue to meet the criteria stated herein.

James And Veronica Shipp Scholarship
HISTORY:
James E. Shipp received his bachelor’s degree in education from Western in 1964. Shipp began his
career in 1964 in the Juvenile Justice System for the State of Illinois, and later with the City of Chicago.
Four years after graduating from WIU, he was selected to participate in the first National Urban Fellow
class and was assigned to fieldwork with the Bedford Stuyvesant Restoration Corporation in Brooklyn,
NY. Shipp eventually became vice president of the Bed-Stuy Corporation until 1979. In addition to his work with the Restoration Corporation, he also served as a director of several city, state and national organizations focused on urban development issues.. In addition to serving as president and CEO of Shipp
Enterprises, LLC in White Plains, NY, Shipp has maintained a commitment and dedication to public
service by continuing to serve on such boards as the South Bronx Overall Economic Development
Corporation, the Mid Bronx Desperados Community Housing Corporation and the Gillen Brewer School
for children with disabilities.
While a student at WIU, Shipp was a member of Tau Kappa Epsilon fraternity and was a record-setting,
conference champion and national finalist wrestler. Shipp was inducted into the WIU Athletic Hall of
Fame in 1997 and received the WIU Distinguished Alumnus Award in 1996. Shipp also received an
honorary Doctorate from WIU in May of 2018. He remains an active member of his alma mater as a
member of the WIU President’s National Advisory Board.
CRITERIA:
• African-American incoming freshmen student
• Preferably first-generation college student
• Minimum 2.75 GPA
• Major in the university’s STEM (science, technology, engineering or math) programs. (A change in majors terminates their eligibility for funding from these resources.)
• Students must submit an essay describing their interest in the major selected.
TERMS:
Award amount is $4000 per year. Amount will be applied to the student’s university account, half
Fall and half Spring. When accumulated income is sufficient for more than one scholarship, two or
more recipients may be selected.
Automatically be eligible for funding for the next three years if they maintain a 2.75 for each
academic year. more...

Jesse J. Lopez, Give A Kid A Second Chance Scholarship
The Jesse J. Lopez, Give a Kid a Second Chance Scholarship is made possible through the generosity of the Jesse J. Lopez fund. This scholarship provides support to students of Mexican or Irish descent who demonstrate academic excellence. Applicants must be currently enrolled at or admitted to attend College of DuPage.
Applicants must be a full-time student (minimum of 12 credit hours).
Applicants must have and maintain a minimum grade point average (GPA) of 3.0.
Applicants must be of either Mexican or Irish descent.
Applicant must describe in 500 words or less a special attribute, accomplishment, or family situation that sets him or her apart and makes him or her a special candidate for a scholarship. In addition, applicants must describe their educational goals and career aspirations as well as how the scholarship will help them achieve these goals more...

John Belushi Choral Scholarship
The John Belushi Choral Scholarship supports a choral student at College of DuPage. Established in 1983 from private donations, this scholarship was formed in the name and memory of actor and comedian John Belushi and Second City, a Chicago-based comedic theater group. Applicants must be residents of District 502 (College of DuPage’s district) and possess sufficient experience and background in the performing arts. Applicants must answer supplemental questions regarding their choral experience. Applicants must include two recommendations from educators and/or employers in order to complete the application process. Applicants are responsible for communicating with recommenders to ensure materials are submitted prior to the scholarship deadline. Award: $1,000 more...

John Belushi Jazz/Band Scholarship
The John Belushi Jazz/Band Scholarship was created to support a band student at College of DuPage. Established in 1983 from private donations, this scholarship was created in the name and memory of actor and comedian John Belushi, and Second City, a Chicago-based comedic theatre group. Applicants must be residents of District 502 (College of DuPage’s district) and must have sufficient experience and background in the performing arts. Applicants must complete supplemental questions detailing their experience with instrumental music. Applicants must include two recommendations from educators and/or employers in order to complete the application process. Applicants are responsible for communicating with their recommenders to ensure that materials are submitted prior to the application deadline. Final candidates must audition with an instrumental solo for reviewers in order to be considered for this award. Award: $1,000 more...

John Belushi Orchestra Scholarship
The John Belushi Orchestra Scholarship was created to support an orchestra student. Established in 1983 from private donations in the name and memory of actor and comedian John Belushi and Second City, a Chicago-based comedic theatre group. Applicant must be a resident of District 502 (College of DuPage’s district) and have sufficient experience and background in the performing arts. Applicants must complete supplemental questions detailing their background and experience. Applicants must include two recommendations from educators and/or employers in order to complete the application process. Applicants are responsible for communicating with recommenders to ensure materials are submitted prior to the application deadline. Final candidates must audition with an instrumental solo in order to be considered for this award. Award: $1,000 more...

John Belushi/College Stage Management Scholarship
The John Belushi/College Stage Management Scholarship supports students studying stage management through experiential learning in college theater productions. Established in 1983 from private donations this scholarship was formed in the name and memory of actor and comedian John Belushi, and Second City, a Chicago-based comedic theatre group. Applicant must be a resident of District 502 (College of DuPage’s district), be enrolled in or intend to enroll in THEA 1120 or 1823, and have sufficient experience and background in the performing arts of technical theatre. Applicants must submit one letter of recommendation from an educator and/or employer in order to complete the application process. Applicants are responsible for communicating with recommenders to ensure all materials are submitted prior to the application deadline. Final candidates are required to interview with the theatre faculty scholarship committee in order to be considered for this award. Award: $500 more...

John Belushi/Second City Theatre Scholarship
The John Belushi/Second City Theatre Scholarship supports an acting or technical theatre student with full tuition, fees, and books for one year. This scholarship was established in 1983 from private donations in the name and memory of actor and comedian John Belushi, and Second City, a Chicago-based comedic theatre group. Applicants must be residents of District 502 (College of DuPage’s district) and must have sufficient experience and background in the performing arts or technical theatre. Applicants must include two recommendations from educators and/or employers in order to complete the application process. Applicants are responsible for communicating with their recommenders to ensure all materials are submitted prior to the application deadline. Final candidates will be required to audition with a 1-2 minute monologue of contemporary theatre (comedic or dramatic) in order to be considered for this award. Award: Full tuition for 1 year up to $7,500 more...

John E. "Jack" Cullerton Memorial Endowed Scholarship
Due to a generous gift in the name of John E. “Jack” Cullerton, scholarship money is available to students enrolled as majors within the School of Hospitality Leadership. The John E. “Jack” Cullerton Memorial Endowed Scholarship can augment any additional funding a student may have previously been awarded. A student can only get this award one time during their academic career.
Awarded to undergraduate students enrolled in the School of Hospitality Leadership who demonstrate financial need and are in good academic standing.
To be considered for the scholarship:
Complete the online application
Upload a current resume.
All students enrolled as majors in the School of Hospitality Leadership are eligible, and encouraged, to apply for additional scholarship funding. In addition to financial need, included in the review process is also consideration for cumulative GPA (2.0 or higher), student activity such as belonging to hospitality clubs or holding club leadership positions, and having full or part time jobs in the hospitality industry.
Preference shall be given to those students who have completed or enrolled in the School of Hospitality course: HSP 382 “Managing People In The Hospitality Environment” oo HSP 208 “Managing People and the Chicago Union Environment”.
Students may apply for any, or all, School of Hospitality Leadership scholarships; however, separate applications are needed for each award. In order to be considered for the The John E. “Jack” Cullerton Memorial Endowed Scholarship, you must complete all fields of the online application and upload all supporting documentation as requested per the scholarship requirements.
SCHOLARSHIP APPLICATION DEADLINE: Sunday September 18th, 2022
Please note, in order to be considered for the Cullerton Memorial Endowed Scholarship, you must complete all required fields of the online application. Applications must be completed and submitted online by 11:59:59pm, Sunday, September 19th, 2021. Incomplete or late applications will not be considered. more...

John E. And Mary J. Price Scholarship
The following criteria must be met:
1. Recipient(s) must be a Communication Studies or College of Health and Human Services* major at Eastern Illinois University. Communication Studies awarding in even fiscal years and College of Health and Human Services* awarding in odd fiscal years.
2. Awards will alternate between departments each year.
3. Recipient(s) must be a sophomore, junior or senior.
4. Recipient(s) must have a grade point average of 3.0 or greater.
5. Recipient(s) must be Illinois residents.
6. Recipient(s) must demonstrate financial need. Financial need shall take precedence should all other criteria be equal.
This award is to be announced in the Fall and awarded in the Fall and Spring semester.
*College of Health and Human Services was formerly known as Family and Consumer Sciences (formerly Home Economics)
Keywords: human services, aging, hospitality, financial literacy, dietetics, nutrition more...

John Horan Endowed Scholarship
The John Horan Endowed Scholarship program is for DePaul students from North Lawndale, specifically North Lawndale College Prep High School, in Chicago, IL, as well as students from similar neighborhoods and schools within the city of Chicago. The John Horan Endowed scholarship aims to cover all tuition costs that remain after the recipient has received any other DePaul University awards and federal/state aid that they are eligible for, and is renewable for four years as long as the recipient remains in good academic standing. The John Horan Endowment Scholarship program was established through the generosity of the Steans family, and is named in honor of John Horan, Founder and President Emeritus at North Lawndale College Prep High School, in recognition and gratitude for his more than 40 years of service to young people. more...

Journalism Internship Scholarship
The Journalism Internship Scholarship ensures that students pursuing a degree in journalism have access to internships for credit by providing financial assistance. Eligible students are welcome to apply for financial assistance while completing a journalism-related internship for credit via the College of Communication Internship Program in the Fall 2022 term.
Eligibility
Journalism major, minor, and journalism graduate students
Submit a proposal for a journalism-based internship for credit via the College of Communication Internship Program by the fall deadline or have secured a journalism-based internship for the fall through the College of Communication Internship Program.
Criteria
Cumulative GPA of 2.5 or above for undergraduate journalism majors or minors; cumulative GPA of 3.0 or above for journalism graduate students
Successful completion of at least two JOUR courses
A College of Communication Internship Proposal on file by September 9, 2022
Special consideration for those with unpaid or low-paying internships. more...

Journalism Talented Student Award
This is a tuition only award.
In order to apply, a student must meet and agree to the following criteria:
Incoming freshmen/transfer students:
• Officially enrolled as a full-time student at the time of the award
• Remain in good academic standing
• Agree to the following:
Once on campus, I will demonstrate my intention to pursue a career in journalism by:
1) Active participation in one or more of the student media programs,
OR
2) Participation in co-curricular programs affiliated with the department of Journalism,
OR
3) Working part-time in a professional situation
• Agree to the following:
—I understand that this award may be rescinded if I fail to maintain good academic standing or withdraw from the University,
AND
—I understand that this award may be rescinded if I do not comply with the “Student Conduct Code,”
AND
—I understand that this award may be rescinded if I fail to meet advisor requirements.
Continuing students:
• Officially enrolled as a full-time student at the time of the award
• Remain in good academic standing
• Actively participate and/or qualify in one or more of the following award areas:
Academic Excellence
WEIU Hit Mix
WEIU Newswatch
Photo
Daily Eastern News
Warbler Yearbook
Study Abroad
• Agree to the following:
—I understand that this award may be rescinded if I fail to maintain good academic standing or withdraw from the University,
AND
—I understand that this award may be rescinded if I do not comply with the “Student Conduct Code,”
AND
—I understand that this award may be rescinded if I fail to meet advisor requirements.
According to EIU’s Internal Governing Policy #73, this award is a “Tuition waiver to provide financial assistance to students with academic talent or special status; fees are not waived.” Therefore, students who already have a full tuition waiver or have no room in their financial aid package for tuition assistance are not eligible to receive this award. more...

Joyce S. Crouse Family And Consumer Sciences Scholarship
The following criteria must be met:
1. The recipient(s) must be a full-time student, accepted to Eastern Illinois University.
2. The awards will be issued on a three-year cycle.
3. During the first and second year of the cycle, the recipient(s) must be majoring within the College of Health and Human Services* (CHHS).
4. During the third year of the cycle, the recipient(s) must be registered in the Gerontology Program. If there are no suitable Gerontology candidates, then other CHHS candidates may be considered.
5. If the Gerontology Program ceases to exist at EIU, then all awards will be made to CHHS recipients.
The recipient(s) may be eligible to apply for and receive the award again provided he/she continues to meet the criteria stated above.
This award shall be issued in the Fall semester.
*College of Health and Human Services (CHHS) was formerly known as Family and Consumer Sciences (FCS)
Keywords: human services, aging, hospitality, financial literacy, dietetics, nutrition more...

Jt Legal Group Law Scholarship
The passion and commitment of a student with ambitions and dreams towards the enhancements of society are characteristics that JT Legal Group sincerely acknowledges. Higher education brings opportunities for prosperity and no obstacle should get in the way of that, especially financial ones. JT Legal Group is looking to award a law school scholarship opportunity in the amount of $5,000 to a student who presents the most equipped and original understanding on the facets of law and legal support.
Eligibility
Must have a GPA above 3.0.
Must submit a completed form along with the essay
Must email the submission to scholarship@jtlegalgroup.com
Must have an interest in pursuing law or is currently pursuing law.
Submission Requirements
A 500 – 1000 word essay
Double-spaced, 12-point font, One-inch margins
File named as your first and last name (Example: Jane_Doe)
Submitted as a doc. or .pdf file.
Essay Prompt
The applicant will be asked to provide an essay explaining the significance of Prop 213 and the potential exceptions that may come with the proposition. In addition, they will explain the importance of helping those not at-fault and what drivers should do if they did get into an uninsured accident.
To learn more and start your application, click on the Visit button below. more...

Julie Svec Memorial Scholarship In Athletics
The Julie Svec Memorial Scholarship in Athletics recognizes an outstanding second-year student pursuing an interest in athletic training, athletic programming/coaching or physical education, and is generously funded through private donations in memory of Julie Svec who served as a College of DuPage Athletic Trainer from 1987 through 1999. Applicants must be student-athletic trainers (working in the training room), student team managers, physical education majors, or students involved in extra-curricular sports activity. Applicants must have completed 12 credit hours with a cumulative GPA or better of 2.5 or higher. Applicants must be enrolled in at least 12 credit hours for the applicable semester. Applicants must submit a letter of recommendation from an athletic trainer, professor or coach. Applicants are responsible for communicating with their recommenders to ensure all materials are submitted prior to the application deadline. Applicants must submit a one-page personal statement about their experience at College of DuPage in order to complete the application process. Award: $1,000 more...

Kanoski Bresney Stand Up To Distracted Driving Scholarship
Distracted driving, including due to texting and other cell phone use, is a serious issue that leads to hundreds of thousands of accidents and injuries in the United States each year. The problem is especially prominent among teen and young adult drivers, and teens are also at a greater risk of being the victim of a distracted driving accident. At Kanoski Bresney, we want to support students who do their part to fight the problem of distracted driving. Through the Kansoki Bresney Stand Up to Distracted Driving Scholarship program, we are offering five scholarships, in the amount of $1,000 each, to students in the U.S. who are pursuing higher education at the undergraduate or graduate level.
Eligibility
You are eligible for the Kanoski Bresney Stand Up to Distracted Driving Scholarship if the following are true:
You are currently enrolled in an undergraduate or graduate program at an accredited U.S. college or university, and your education will continue through at least the Spring 2023 semester, OR
You are a high school senior who will be starting your college or university education in Spring 2023.
You are a U.S. citizen.
You have a current overall GPA of at least 3.0.
Application Instructions
In order to be considered for the scholarship, you must submit a 1,000-word essay responding to the following prompt:
How has distracted driving affected your life? What ideas do you have to raise awareness of the dangers of distracted driving and prevent this behavior among young drivers?
Your essay should be double-spaced, with 12-point font and one-inch margins, and saved as a .doc, .docx, or .pdf file with a file name that includes your first and last name.
In addition to your essay, you will need to submit a current academic transcript, contact information including your name, phone number, address, and email address, and a professional photograph of yourself.
To learn more and start your application, click on the Visit button below. more...

Be an undergraduate major in Hospitality Leadership
Completion of the online application
All students enrolled as majors in the School of Hospitality Leadership are eligible, and are encouraged to apply for the scholarship funding. In addition to financial need (as determined by the FAFSA), included in the review process is also consideration for cumulative GPA, student activity such as belonging to hospitality clubs or holding club leadership positions, or having full or part time jobs in the hospitality industry.

Keith And Carol Sanders Alumni Scholarship
The Keith and Carol Sanders Alumni Scholarship is designed to encourage high-achieving, low-income students from Benton Consolidated High School in Benton, Illinois to attend Southern Illinois University Carbondale, especially if they are from an alumni family.
Scholarship for an incoming freshman from Benton Consolidated High School. If no students from Benton Consolidated High School are eligible, then students from Franklin County, Illinois, may be considered.
Recipient must be in the top 40% of their high school class and must provide three (3) letters of recommendation from persons of authority at their high school.
Preference shall be given to qualified candidates who are from an alumni family. An alumni family is defined as one in which the candidate has a mother, father, sister, brother, or spouse who has graduated from SIU Carbondale or any other family member, provided the applicant has a strong letter of recommendation from the family member who is an alumnus.
Scholarship is automatically renewable for an additional academic year (total of 4 consecutive semesters) as long as recipient maintains a minimum 3.0 cumulative GPA and full-time status. more...

Applicants may not reside in the following Illnois counties: Sangamon, Greene, Macoupin, Madison, Montgomery, Christian, Scott, Pike, Shelby, Moultrie, Piatt, Champaign, Macon, Logan, McLean, Woodford, Tazewell, Peoria, Fulton, Mason, Menard, Cass, Morgan, Brown, or Schuyler. Nonrenewable. more...

L. Joyce Taylor Student Teaching Scholarship
The following criteria must be met:
1. The recipients(s) must be a full-time student at Eastern Illinois University in a major leading to Teacher Certification and must be in good academic standing. In addition, recipients must have completed all requirements to become eligible to student teach and must be approved to student teach within the next 12 months after the award date.
2. Financial need is a consideration. This award has been established to offset the cost of student teaching expenses in order to overcome the financial barriers that exist on the way to becoming an excellent educator.
3. The application process for this scholarship shall include the submission by each applicant of a one-page essay outlining future educational and career plans. This essay should address how the applicant has overcome adversity, obstacles, or barriers in his/her life, and how he/she has experienced the impact of teaching in underserved populations prior to the application for this scholarship.
4. Within the essay in the above criteria, the recipient shall demonstrate a commitment to teaching underserved populations.
Students may not be eligible to receive the award a second time.
This award will be open for applications in both the fall and spring semester to disburse the following semester of which it was announced. more...

Lasalle Real Estate Scholarship For Black And Latinx Minorities
The Program: The LaSalle Real Estate Scholarship for Black and Latinx Minorities was created by LaSalle Investment Management with the express objective of providing commercial real estate exposure and experience to qualified Black and Latinx college students. The scholarship program spans multiple colleges and universities, and includes individual student annual scholarships of $10,000. Scholarship recipients will have the opportunity to participate in a rigorous, educational self-study program resulting in a coveted certification.
Requirements: Students receiving the scholarship must complete three requirements:
• Maintain 3.0 GPA
• Attend four quarterly LaSalle Investment Management meetings (online)
• Participate in a monthly LaSalle mentorship program
Internship: Scholars are encouraged to apply for the LaSalle Investment Management summer internship program in Chicago. Interviews will be guaranteed for all scholars who apply but only one internship opportunity may be available; participation in required events and mentorship program will be taken into consideration
Eligibility: To be eligible for the LaSalle Real Estate Scholarship for Black and Latinx Minorities, an individual must be a rising sophomore of Black/African American origin or Hispanic/Latinx origin. The scholarship is open to all majors.
*Awards: *An award may be used toward the payment of tuition, fees, and books, but may not be applied to such incidental expenses as travel and lodging. An individual who has received a LaSalle Real Estate Scholarship for Black and Latinx Minorities scholarship is eligible to apply for additional financial aid. Scholarship funds will be disbursed in three equal installments each quarter.
This scholarship will be awarded for the 2022-2023 academic year from LaSalle Investment Management. The deadline to apply is July 20th,11:59:59 p.m. more...

Learn To Become.Com
ollege can be expensive for anyone, but it can be especially costly for those with disabilities. Some classroom accommodations are paid for out-of-pocket, medical bills tend to be much higher, and even transportation costs can be greater than what a typical student would have to pay to get to and from class. These are just a few of the reasons why it’s so important for students with disabilities to have ample funding options available to them. This guide focuses on those options, with the goal of helping students with disabilities find the resources they need to pay for and succeed in college. more...

Award amount is equal to half-tuition. Number of awards varies. Renewable. more...

Leroy Daniels Scholarship
The Leroy Daniels Scholarship was established in 1986 by the Gwendolyn Brooks Cultural Center and community donors including the late Lois Mills, WIU Librarian, in memory of Leroy W. Daniels. Daniels was employed at WIU from September 1968 until his death in August 1984. Leroy, along with his brother Joe, was one of the organizers and a charter member of the McDonough County Chapter of the NAACP (established in 1968). He served as president for more than 11 years.
CRITERIA:
Minimum 2.5 cumulative GPA

Minority student
Illinois resident
Demonstrated evidence of leadership activities in college or the community is desired
Preference is given to a student graduate of Macomb Senior High School more...

Levinson Law Group Annual Scholarship Contest
We at the Levinson Law Group are passionate advocates against drunk driving.
As sponsors of MADD (Mothers Against Drunk Driving), we commit ourselves every year to doing what we can to end injuries and fatalities due to drunk driving.
According to MADD:
A person is injured in a drunk driving crash every 120 seconds
Every day in America, 28 people are killed in drunk driving crashes
Two in three people, on average, will be involved in a drunk driving crash in their lifetime
We have represented many clients who have been victims of drunk driving, so we know the devastating affects a drunk driving accident can have on an individual and their loved ones.
To help victims of drunk driving, we now offer a scholarship to undergraduate students whose lives have been affected by drunk driving.
The Levinson Law Group Undergraduate Scholarship for Victims of Drunk Driving
To qualify for the $1,500 scholarship for undergraduate students, you must write an essay illustrating how you have been personally affected by a drunk driving accident. You or a loved one could be a victim in a crash, but it must have impacted your life.
The essay must be 500 words.
Eligibility Rules
Applicants must be either out-going high school seniors (graduating summer 2019) or students currently enrolled in a college, trade school, or university as of the start of the fall 2019 semester.
Send your essay, a picture of your school ID, and your school information to gordon@levinsonlawgroup.com
The essay must be submitted by Thursday, August 1, 2019.
A winner will be selected by no later than Thursday, August 15, 2019. more...

Lewis E. Wall Scholarship

CRITERIA:
Information Management major
Minimum of 60 semester hours completed by the end of the semester of application
Minimum 3.0 GPA

Lgbtq Studies Creative And Scholarly Works Contest -- Undergraduate
The LGBTQ Studies Program’s Creative and Scholarly Works Contest is open to all DePaul undergraduate students, regardless of home college. We accept essays and projects in the interdisciplinary field of LGBTQ Studies. The submissions may come from any discipline, and they must address a topic, theme, or issue relevant to LGBTQ Studies. Works can be research-based essays or creative writing, as well as work done in other media such as film, design, or web pages. There is no length requirement. Entrants need not be in the LGBTQ Studies minor program. In addition to a $250 cash prize, there may be an opportunity to be published in Creating Knowledge, the undergraduate research journal of the College of Liberal Arts and Social Sciences. In addition, the prize winner will be recognized at the Annual Lavender Graduation. Submissions may have originated within a course or outside of a course.
Please upload your body of work to this application.
In order to qualify:
Essays must be 25 pages or less.
The work must be previously unpublished work.
Visual art must be accompanied with a short, written explanatory statement.
Submissions may not contain any names on the body of work — anything with a name will be disqualified. more...

Lgbtq Studies Creative And Scholarly Works Contest ‚Äì Graduate
The LGBTQ Studies Program’s Graduate Creative and Scholarly Works Contest is open to all DePaul graduate students, regardless of home college. We accept essays and projects in the interdisciplinary field of LGBTQ Studies. Submissions may come from any discipline, and they must address a topic, theme, or issue relevant to LGBTQ Studies. Works can be research-based essays or creative writing, as well as work done in other media such as film, design, or web pages. There is no length requirement. In addition to a $250 cash prize, the prize-winner will be recognized at the Annual Lavender Graduation. Submissions may have originated within a course or outside of a course.
In order to qualify:
Essays must be 25 pages or less.
The work must be previously unpublished work.
Visual art must be accompanied with a short, written explanatory statement.
Submissions may not contain any names on the body of work — anything with a name will be disqualified. more...

Lillian R. Greathouse Scholarship
The following criteria must be met:
1. The recipient(s) must be an incoming freshman, incoming transfer student, or senior, accepted and registered at Eastern Illinois
University as a full-time student, majoring in career and technical education. Once a recipient receives the award as an incoming
freshman or incoming transfer student, a senior is eligible to apply for the award again provided that the recipient still meets the
criteria.
2. The freshman recipient(s) must be in the top 20% of his/her high school graduating class.
3. The recipient(s) must submit an essay addressing the following: a. characteristics that a good teacher must have, b. why I want to
be a teacher, and c. why I want to teach career and technical education specifically.
4. The transfer and/or senior recipient(s) must have an overall GPA of 2.65 to continue receiving the award.
This award shall be announced in the Spring and disbursed in the Fall semester. more...

Linda And Robert Jenkins Endowed Paralegal Studies Scholarship
Linda and Robert Jenkins Endowed Paralegal Studies Scholarship encourages academic excellence in the Paralegal Program. Applicant must be currently enrolled in or admitted to College of DuPage, be pursuing a degree or certificate in Paralegal Studies, have completed at least 3 paralegal (PLGL) classes. Applicants pursuing an associate degree in Paralegal Studies must have a cumulative GPA or better of 3.25 or higher and a Paralegal Studies GPA or better of 3.6 or higher. Applicants pursuing a Paralegal Studies certificate must have a Paralegal Studies GPA or better of 3.6 or higher. Applicants must submit a 750-word essay describing their career goals and involvement in extra-curricular, legal-related activities. Students must demonstrate leadership or active involvement in College of DuPage’s Paralegal Club, or be actively involved with another volunteer organization in the legal field. Finalists will be selected by a Review Committee including the Paralegal Studies Program Coordinator, members of the Paralegal Studies faculty, and Paralegal Studies alumni. Award: 2 at $500 more...

Lois Liehr Education Scholarship
The Lois. E. Licht Education Scholarship was established in 2018 by her nephew, Daniel B. Licht, as
a means to honor her upon her passing in September 2017. Lois graduated in 1951 with a Bachelor
of Science in Education. Lois taught elementary school for over 30 years, retiring as a second grade
teacher in Sterling, Illinois. Having been burn and raised in Perry, Illinois attending Dexter School
there, and with all family roots in Pike County, this scholarship is to be awarded to a high school
graduate from Pike County, Illinois who chooses to pursue a career in education.
CRITERIA;
Freshman education major, all areas, including early childhood, elementary, middle, and secondary s
subject specific education
Recipient must have graduated from a secondary school in Pike County, Illinois

Lori & Eric Swanson Paralegal Scholarship
The Fund intends to establish a scholarship that awards a student who had to overcome a significant life event that interfered with the ability to pursue College or is currently going through difficult circumstances that interfered with the ability to continue College, such as:
- Being a parent of a special needs or disabled child/adult.
- Being a family caregiver for an elderly parent, special needs, or disabled child/adult.
- A single parent who had to put off College to raise child(ren).
The student will have had to have completed PLGL 1100, Introduction to Paralegal Studies, and received a grade of “B” or better, in order to be eligible to receive this scholarship.
The money from this Fund is intended to cover in-district tuition and fees plus the cost of textbooks/eBooks /online course subscriptions for required paralegal program courses only necessary to complete the paralegal studies certificate or degree. more...

Lou Ann And Tom Waskom Scholarship
The following criteria must be met:
1. A minimum of two scholarships shall be awarded annually. One recipient(s) must be a full-time student, majoring in Career and
Technical Education with an option in Technology Education, accepted to Eastern Illinois University. The second recipient(s) must be a
full-time student, majoring in Engineering Technology, accepted to Eastern Illinois University. In the circumstance that there
is not a qualified recipient in one of the majors above, then the committee may elect to award additional awards to the other major.
2. The recipient(s) must have completed a minimum of 60 credit hours at Eastern Illinois University.
3. The recipient(s) must have a minimum cumulative GPA of 2.50.
4. The recipients must be a high school graduate of one of the following counties in Illinois; Coles, Effingham, Cumberland, Shelby, and
Edgar. If there are no qualified applicants from the counties above, those students from surrounding counties will be considered.
This award shall be announced in the Spring and disbursed in the Fall semester. more...

Lucille M. Klehm Technology Education Award
The following criteria must be met:
1. Nominations for the award shall be made under the procedures to be determined by the Committee.
2. The recipient must be a full-time student, majoring in Career and Technical Education with an emphasis in Technology Education.
Only if there is no qualified Career and Technical Education with an emphasis in Technology Education applicant, the recipient must be an undergraduate majoring in one of the technology-related majors offered by the School of Technology, accepted to Eastern Illinois University who plans to pursue a career in technical education (e.g. high schools, vocational centers, community colleges, universities).
3. The recipient must be a student in good academic standing at Eastern Illinois University.
4. The financial need of the candidate(s) shall be a criterion to the extent determined by the committee.
5. Other criteria shall include personal qualities and participation in departmental activities.
6. The recipient may be eligible to apply for the award again provided he/she continues to meet criteria.
This award is announced in the Spring and disbursed in the Fall. more...

Lydia Molinari Olson Memorial Radiation Therapy Scholarship
Lydia Molinari Olson Memorial Radiation Therapy Scholarship. Lydia worked in Radiation Therapy for over 30 years. She was a dedicated professional both as a therapist and instructor in the program at College of DuPage. Lydia taught at the College of DuPage from the inception of the Radiation Therapy Program in 2006 until her retirement in 2019; she was key to bringing the program to its success today. Lydia provided excellent care and heartfelt compassion for her students and patients.
The purpose of the annual scholarship award is to provide financial assistance to a student enrolled in the full-time Radiation Therapy Program, has demonstrated above-average academic skills and has had work experience in the health care field. Financial needs may also be considered.
Current College of DuPage Student enrolled full-time in the Radiation Therapy Program
Applicants must demonstrate above-average academic skills
Applicant must have previous work experience in the health care field.
Financial need may be considered
*Educational expenses limited to tuition, fees, or books. more...

Marc Jacobson Blue Demon Scholarship
THE MARC JACOBSON BLUE DEMON SCHOLARSHIP has been established at DePaul University in support of the Jesse White Tumbling Team scholar-athletes to provide assistance to one full-time student who will work as a Student Assistant for the Director of Athletics in the area of Diversity, Equity and Inclusion.
Marc Jacobson is a DePaul University alum and enthusiastic supporter of the Jesse White Tumbling Team Organization.
SCHOLARSHIP APPLICANT CRITERIA:
Applicant must be an undergraduate level student admitted to DePaul for the upcoming academic year as a full-time Freshman or Transfer student OR a currently enrolled full-time undergraduate student at DePaul returning for the upcoming academic year.
Applicant must be in good academic standing and demonstrate need as determined by the FAFSA.
Preference will be given to students who are alumni of the Jesse White Tumblers.
Applicants must complete and submit the scholarship application by the deadline in order to be considered.
SCHOLARSHIP DETAILS:
Scholarship Award will cover tuition, room and board (on-campus), and University fees
Open to all academic majors
Each award shall be made for one academic year and is renewable for the same student provided that they remain in good academic standing with the University and continues to work as a Student Assistant for the Director of Athletics in the area of Diversity, Equity and Inclusion. more...

Marchet Harts Communication Scholarship Award For Women Of Color
This scholarship is established by WIU 2003 Communication Alumna Minda Harts in honor of her mother, Marchet Harts who graduated from the Western Illinois University Quad Cities campus in 2004. Minda decided to “create this scholarship to help future women students of color the ability to thrive with financial assistance to help ease the burden of tuition and books. As a woman of color it is important to me for students to see there are alumni rooting for their success. It was important to put this scholarship in my mother’s name as a way to show gratitude for her rooting me on at each stage of my career. I hope the recipients of this scholarship will pay it forward to future students of color in the Communication department.”
Minda holds a Bachelor’s in Communication from Western Illinois University. She has more than a decade of fundraising and sales experience and has been part of successful fundraising campaigns at The University of Texas at Austin, UCLA, and Duke. Minda is the founder of The Memo LLC, a career development company for women of color. In 2016, she was nominated as a Change Maker at The White House State of Women Summit. Minda is a member of the New York Junior League and volunteers at women’s shelters across NYC; helping women enhance their resumes and interviewing skills. Additionally, she serves as a mentor at General Assembly in New York City. Minda conducts workshops and keynotes at corporations like Time Inc., The Campaign For Black Male Achievement, and The New York Public Library. She has been featured in Forbes Magazine, Essence Magazine, The Guardian, and The Huffington Post.
CRITERIA:
Woman of color
Incoming Freshman or Transferring Junior
Student should pursue a Communication major in any related discipline with the Department of Communication, and demonstrate a desire to graduate and contribute to said career field.
Applicant should write a one to two-page essay on their career aspirations. The essay should include how the student plans to give back to their alma mater after graduation.
To be considered, applicants must also agree to participate in a mentorship opportunity with Minda Harts, which will include at least one phone call and one video call per semester. more...

Marriott Hospitality Ambassador Program (Mhap)
The relationship between Marriott International (MI) and DePaul’s School of Hospitality Leadership (SHL) has developed into a strong and productive partnership. In the spirit of continuously strengthening this relationship with MI, the SHL is excited to launch the Marriott Hospitality Ambassador Program (MHAP). At the completion of a rigorous selection process that takes a holistic view of applicant qualifications (GPA, personal essay, letters of recommendation, interview to identify soft skill proficiency, and a strong desire to work for MI), a current SHL student will be granted the prestigious title of Marriott Ambassador.
Marriott Ambassador will engage in the following:
1. MI Brand Familiarization: To ensure familiarity within the MI brand portfolio, the Marriott Ambassador will tour Marriott Chicago Business Council hotels. These tours highlight the similarities and differences across brands, and provide an opportunity for the Marriott Ambassador to interact with MI senior leadership.
2. Senior Leadership Mentorship: The Marriott Ambassador will receive professional development through a mentorship from a dedicated Marriott Business Council General Manager.
3. Classroom Engagement: SHL faculty frequently bring hospitality leaders into their classroom to discuss practical application of industry concepts. To ensure that MI is well represented across a variety of hospitality courses, the Marriott Ambassador will facilitate incorporation of MI leadership into the SHL learning environment in both undergraduate- and graduate-level courses. This includes all levels of Marriott leadership, including recent SHL graduates who are participating in Marriott’s Voyage program.
4. Career Guidance and Placement: Experience has shown that hospitality industry career preparation and placement occurs year round. In addition to looking for open jobs and internships, students will also benefit from interactions with hospitality firms at career fairs, dedicated information sessions, and guest speaking engagements. The Marriott Ambassador will assist SHL faculty, staff, and students to become familiar with Marriott career opportunities. In addition to interacting with corporate and property-level recruiters, the Marriott Ambassador will also be available to promote Marriott and to answer student questions on an individual basis.
The top 3 applicants will be contacted for an interview. more...

Martha T. And Lavern M. Hamand Memorial Scholarship (Graduate Writing Award)
The following criteria must be met:
1. The recipient(s) must be a graduate student enrolled in the department of History’s traditional or Historical Administration program, accepted to Eastern Illinois University.
2. The recipient(s) must be in good academic standing and have achieved an outstanding grade point average.
3. Preference shall be given to the candidate who can demonstrate outstanding scholarly achievement with an emphasis on historical writing as determined by submission of a writing assignment from a Master’s level class and/or chapter from the student’s master’s thesis.
4. Financial need may be a consideration.
5. Should the master’s degree in History and Historical Administration cease to exist, the award may be given as a writing award to an undergraduate History major.
6. The recipient may be eligible to apply for, and receive, the award again provided he/she continues to meet the critieria.
7. One recipient is selected each semester – for fall and spring. Separate application periods will be open for each semester. more...

Recipients must be a current and active member of either Alpha Gamma Rho fraternity or Sigma Alpha Sorority. One recipient will be selected from each organization.
Preference will be given to applicants who are first-generation college students. more...

Mathematics Alumni Scholarship
These are scholarships awarded to students through the generosity of alumni of the Department of Mathematics. CRITERIA: Freshmen must be recommended by two high school teachers addressing the student?۪s interest in mathematics and potential to succeed in a career related to mathematics; and must remain a math major for the period of the scholarship. Continuing students must be recommended by two faculty members addressing the student?۪s interest in mathematics and potential to succeed in a career related to mathematics; and must remain a math major for the period of the scholarship. Incoming freshman must have an ACT math score of at least 23 or be in the upper 25% on an equivalent national assessment of mathematics ability and must be in the upper 20% of the student?۪s high school graduating class. Continuing students must have an overall college grade point average of 3.0 or higher on a 4-point scale (students with less than 30 semester hours must submit a copy of ACT or other standardized test scores) and must have a 3.0 or higher grade point average in mathematics courses that count in the major (the number of mathematics courses completed will be one consideration). Transfer students must be transferring with mathematics as the intended major; must have an overall college grade point average of 3.0 or higher on a 4-point scale (students with less than 30 semester hours must submit a copy of ACT or other standardized test scores) and must have a 3.0 or higher grade point average in mathematics courses that count in the major (the number of mathematics courses completed will be one consideration). more...

Scholarship for undergraduate students attending Xavier University who are majoring in Mathematics or Computer Science. Selection based on merit and financial need. Renewable. more...

Matthew Dickson Memorial Scholarship
Matthew Dickson Memorial Scholarship
June 11, 1981-March 25, 2021
Matthew “Matt” Paul Dickson was a husband, son, brother, uncle, grandson, son-in-law, and Purple Heart-honored Marine veteran. He was all of these things and also so very much more. He was a crazy good dancer, a lover of a good scotch, and was aggressively competitive at all sports and games. He had the greatest smile and, based on his own judgement, an award-winning beard. If you were loved by Matt, you would find no greater champion.
Matt married Brittany Scotto on October 8, 2016, in Kansas City. He loved his wife, Britt. She was his person and the life they built together was uniquely theirs: beautiful, funny, spontaneous and wonderful. She was his light and his life.
He loved his parents Mike and Leslie. He got his sense of duty and commitment to family, community and country from them. Having their love meant the world to him.
He loved his siblings by birth (Michelle and Brett) and his siblings by marriage (Lee and Brittany). As the oldest, it was his job to both protect and annoy them, and he took both seriously. He saw being a brother as a privilege.
He loved his nieces and nephew, and all of his friends’ children who also called him Uncle Matt. While he planned on being a dad, he already excelled at being an uncle. Being Uncle Matt let his sense of humor and silliness shine, and he was so proud of Ellie, Kaylie, Claire and Carter.
Matt was a three-sport letterman on the varsity soccer, basketball and baseball teams at Glenwood High School, graduating in 2000. He attended the University of Illinois in Champaign and Southern Illinois University in Carbondale. He was a US Marine and served two tours of duty in Iraq (2003 and 2004). Matt was a director at a digital marketing agency in Kansas City.
He loved his friends. While too numerous to list here, his friends were so important to him. Whether it was with his Marine brothers-in-arms, in the backyard around a fire pit, at a musical festival, playing golf, or just hanging out in the driveway with a few beers, he thrived being in the middle of the fray. His friends fed his soul.
He loved his dogs, Wrigley and Ivy. They were his companions, his playmates, his partners in crime.
Matt was beloved by an army of friends, family and coworkers who will miss his insane wit, his belly laugh, his intense sense of humor, his cooking, and his solid IPA recommendations. There is no greater privilege to have known him and no greater tragedy to have lost him.
To continue Matthew Dickson’s legacy of service, leadership, laughter, hope and strength, his parents, Mike and Leslie have established a scholarship and award endowment for students attending Lincoln Land Community College.
ELIGIBILITY
1. Minimum GPA of 2.5 on a 4.0 scale
2. Enrolled in any program of study
3. Available for a first-time or continuing college student
4. Enrolled in a minimum of 6 credit hours
5. Preference given to a United States Veteran and Chatham Glenwood High School graduate more...

Matthew G. Mcguinness Memorial Scholarship
Scholarship for male non-traditional undergraduate students attending Western Illinois University who are majoring in Kinesiology. Applicants must have a minimum 2.75 GPA, completed 24 credit hours at WIU and be 25 years of age or older. Number of awards may vary. Renewable. more...

Matthew H. Mcguinness Memorial Scholarship
The Matthew H. McGuinness Memorial Scholarship was established by Denise Otto McGuinness in memory of her son, Matthew. CRITERIA: Kinesiology major, Non-traditional student (generally a student 25 years of age or older who started college later in life; or one whose education was interrupted and is now returning to campus to complete his or her degree), Undergraduate class level and must have completed at least 24 semester hours of coursework at WIU, Minimum 2.75 GPA, Demonstrated involvement in the Macomb community. more...

Maurice G Kellogg Scholarship
The Maurice G. Kellogg Scholarship Fund was established by Dr. Maurice G. Kellogg. This award is intended to support the continued professional development and recognition of primary science teachers and WIU students. CRITERIA: Entering freshman, Intent to major in Elementary Education, Graduate of a high school in Hancock or Fulton County in Illinois, If there is no qualified student from Hancock or Fulton County, then a graduate from any Illinois high school may be considered, ACT of 26 or above or an equivalent score on a like test or be in the upper 15% of their high school class, Financial need, Evidence of involvement in high school and community activities (i.e. youth groups, academic clubs, scholastic teams, etc., especially in a leadership role). Additional consideration may be given to the students who have indicated an interest in and/or strong performance in science, Courses taken in science, GPA in science and possible interest in teaching elementary science, although not a major criterion, should be considered in the final selection of the scholarship recipient. more...

Max Runkle Endowed Scholarship For Biology
Max William Runkle, a native of Macomb, Illinois, was a proud graduate of Western Illinois University earning a Master’s degree in Wildlife Biology in 1968. He spent his career of 40 years with the Illinois Department of Natural Resources, passionately caring for the state’s natural and wildlife resources. He authored many articles and was sought for his knowledge and passion regarding conversation and wildlife. Possessing great intellect himself, he valued learning and opportunity. Max spent his life, not only his career, dedicated to preserving our state’s natural resources.
Max Runkle was the quintessential outdoorsman and conservationist. He loved hiking, flying, sailing, camping, canoeing, biking, fly fishing, and walking for hours in the woods.
CRITERIA:
New freshman
Biology major
Minimum 3.0 GPA


ACT 24+ or SAT 1160+
Full-time enrollment
First preference to zoology major option more...

Maxene Brooks Scholarship
Maxene graduated from WIU in 1940 with a Bachelors of Education. She taught at Francis Millard in Rock Island.
CRITERIA:
Incoming transfer student transferring min of 30 sem hours
Minimum transfer GPA of 3.2
Demonstration of leadership & community service more...

Maxine Robinson Scholarship
Scholarship for incoming freshmen or transfer students enrolling at Western Illinois University who will be majoring in Elementary Education with an emphasis in Reading. Incoming freshmen must have a minimum ACT score of 25 and graduate in the top 25% of class. Transfer students must have a minimum 3.25 GPA and 30 credit hours. Financial need is considered. Preference given to residents of McDonough County. Number of awards may vary. Nonrenewable. more...

Maxine Robinson Scholarship
The Maxine L. Robinson Scholarship Fund was established by Mrs. Opal Wedeberg to honor her sister Maxine Robinson. CRITERIA: Elementary Education major, Resident of one of 27 west-central Illinois counties* served by WIU, Incoming freshman or transfer: Freshmen must have a minimum 23 ACT and rank in the upper 25% of graduating high school class, Transfer students must have completed a minimum 30 semester hours and have a minimum 3.25 GPA on a 4.0 scale. Evidence of involvement in high school and community activities, Demonstrated financial need, Letter of recommendation from high school counselor, Dean, Principal, or appropriate administrator attesting to the quality and quantity of academic performance and promise as an educator. Preference given to a McDonough County, IL student. more...

Mayes/Mclean Scholarship
The Mayes/McLean Scholarship provides assistance to African American students in Criminal Justice studies, and is funded by the Northern Illinois Chapter of the National Organization of Black Law Enforcement Executives. Applicants must be African American, be enrolled in a minimum of 6 credit hours for the applicable semester, maintain a cumulative GPA or better of 3.0 if they are full-time students (12+ credit hours per semester) or a cumulative GPA or better of 2.5 if they are part-time students (6+ hours per semester), and file the FAFSA for the applicable academic year. Applicants must demonstrate community service experience. Award: $500 more...

Student must have an exceptional record of leadership through community, church, civic or school activities. Candidate must also present a strong academic record, demonstrate financial need, and submit a recommendation letter with application packet. Finalists must attend an interview in April; due date for Transfer student is July 1st; interview date may vary. Number of awards varies. Renewable; with continued commitment to community service. more...

Mcinerney Family Endowed Scholarship In Hospitality Leadership
Due to a generous gift from Mr. Joe McInerney, Founding Chairman of the DePaul School of Hospitality Leadership Advisory Board and national hospitality leader, and his family — the McInerney Family Scholarship was created for students enrolled as majors in the School of Hospitality Leadership. All *undergraduate*students enrolled as majors in the School of Hospitality Leadership are eligible, and are encouraged to apply for the scholarship funding.
In addition to financial need (as determined by the FAFSA), included in the review process is also consideration for cumulative GPA (2.0 or higher), student activity such as belonging to hospitality clubs or holding club leadership positions, or having full or part time jobs in the hospitality industry.
SCHOLARSHIP APPLICATION DEADLINE: Sunday, September 18th, 2022
Please note, in order to be considered for the McInerney Family Endowed Scholarship, you must complete all required fields of the online application. Applications must be completed and submitted online by 11:59:59 PM on Sunday, September 19th, 2021. Incomplete or late applications will not be considered. more...

Mcnabb-Dow Graduate Scholarship
The following criteria must be met:
1. The scholarship recipient must be full-time graduate students, majoring in Family and Sciences, accepted to Eastern Illinois University. One recipient must be in Dietetics. However, if a second qualified dietetics recipient is not available, the second recipient may be in any Family and Consumer Sciences option.
2. Other factors that will be considered are: a) 60% scholarship b) 20% leadership c) 20% service
3. Financial need MAY be considered.
4. The recipient must be in good academic standing.
This award shall be announced in the Fall and paid in the Fall semester.
Keywords: human services, aging, hospitality, financial literacy, dietetics, nutrition more...

Memorial Health Scholarship
One of the leading healthcare organizations in Illinois, Memorial Health is a community-based, not-for-profit corporation dedicated to patient care, education and research. Memorial Health’s Mission is “to improve the health of the people and communities we serve.” The Vision is “to be the health system people choose over all others.”
Memorial Health has established a scholarship for students enrolled in Lincoln Land Community College’s (LLCC) Associate Degree Nursing (ADN) Program with the following provisions and guidelines.
I. The recipient of the scholarship must be a resident of the Lincoln Land Community College District 526 or meet the residency qualifications established by LLCC for in-district tuition rates and be a United States citizen or granted permanent resident status.
II. Recipient(s) must meet the following qualifications:
a. Must be accepted in LLCC’s ADN Program.
b. Minimum grade point average of 2.8 on a 4.0 scale.
c. Enroll and complete the minimum credit hours (10 credit hours) per semester required by the ADN Program.
III. The recipient(s) must maintain the minimum grade point average and complete the enrolled hours required each semester.
IV. Scholarship recipient(s) will be encouraged to meet with Memorial Health representatives throughout his/her enrollment in the ADN Program. more...

Mensa Education & Research Foundation Scholarship
Mensa Foundation scholarships are awarded on the basis of an essay that describes the applicant’s career, academic and/or vocational goals. The scholarships are unrestricted as to age, race, gender, level of education, grade point average, or financial need. The scholarship application process is open Sept. 15 – Jan. 15. Applicants must be enrolled in a degree program in an accredited U.S. institution of higher learning during the academic year following the application date. more...

Michael & Dianne Shanley Endowed Scholarship In The School Of Continuing And Professional Studies
SCPS – Awarded to an undergraduate student enrolled in the School of Continuing and Professional Studies who is in good academic standing and exhibits financial need. Preference given to minority students.
You MUST be enrolled in at least six credit hours during the quarter in order to meet the eligibility requirements for the scholarship.
This scholarship requires you to upload a copy of your unofficial transcript. If you have not already done so, please go back to the General Application to upload.
**If you are awarded a scholarship, you will receive notification on your Financial Aid Award. You will also be notified via the DePaul Online Scholarship Application.
For additional information about the scholarship application process, please visit http://www.scps.depaul.edu/admission-and-aid/Pages/aid-and-scholarships.aspx more...

The Michael and Sandra Meyers Scholarship assists students who are in need of financial aid to pursue their educational dreams. Applicants must be currently enrolled in or admitted to College of DuPage, be enrolled in at least 6 credit hours for the applicable semester, have and maintain a cumulative GPA or better of 2.5 or higher, and complete the FAFSA for the applicable academic year. Applicant must provide a one-page essay describing their career goals and how this scholarship will help in reaching their dreams. Preference will be given to District 502 residents (College of DuPage’s district), but non-residents may apply. Award: $1,000 more...

Michael Ries Alumni Scholarship
The Michael Ries Alumni Scholarship offers a scholarship to a student in need of financial assistance and who meets the necessary criteria. This scholarship is funded by the College of DuPage Alumni Association in honor of COD alumnus Michael Ries. Applicants must be residents of District 502 (College of DuPage’s district), be enrolled as a full-time student (12 credit hours or more) for the applicable semester, have a cumulative GPA or better of 3.5 or higher, and file the FAFSA for the applicable academic year. Applicants must demonstrate collegiate or community involvement and submit 2 letters of recommendation from instructors. Applicants are responsible for communicating with their recommenders to ensure the submission of all materials prior to the application deadline. Award: $500 more...
